item.title: Turkish President Returns to Istanbul in Sign Military Coup Is Faltering
item.description: Vowing that faction leaders will “pay a heavy price,” President Recep Tayyip Erdogan made a dramatic appearance after his supporters flooded the streets of Turkey’s largest city.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO and CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: News Analysis: U.S. Finds Itself on Shakier Ground as Erdogan Confronts Mutiny
item.media:description: An overturned car in Ankara, Turkey, on Saturday.
item.description: Even though the coup attempt appeared to be failing by early Saturday morning in Turkey, the country has suddenly become another tumultuous one in a region that knows no end of turmoil.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Tumult in Turkey: The Key Players
item.media:description: Turkish soldiers stood guard on Friday near Taksim Square in Istanbul.
item.description: About four hours after an apparent coup attempt by a faction of military forces in Turkey, the movement appeared to be faltering.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: A Surly Misfit With No Terror Links Turned a Truck Into a Tank
item.media:description: People brought flowers on Friday to the site of the previous night’s attack in Nice, France.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.description: The suspect in the rampage that killed 84 people in Nice had run-ins with the law but no record of radicalization, and left no declaration of a motive.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: In France, the Mood Darkens as a Harsh Reality Sets In
item.media:description: A police officer passed a makeshift shrine on the Promenade des Anglais in Nice on Friday.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: In an aftermath different from those in previous attacks, ordinary citizens and political opposition leaders after the Nice episode questioned whether enough had been done to protect the country.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: In Truck Attack in Nice, Mainstay of Commerce Reinvented as Tool of Death
item.media:description: The truck used in the rampage in Nice, France, was moved Friday from the scene of the attack.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: The rampage opened a frightening new landscape of terrorism, using a weapon that is ubiquitous on roads in the United States and was encouraged by Al Qaeda years ago.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI

item.title: In Nice, a Vibrant Celebration Gives Way to a Trail of Death
item.media:description: A woman received help after being injured Thursday night by a truck that plowed into a crowd in Nice, France, killing dozens.
item.description: A speeding truck that barreled into a crowd on Bastille Day left a trail of bodies, shock and despair.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Truck Attack in Nice, France: What We Know, and What We Don’t
item.description: President François Hollande said it was a terrorist attack, but authorities didn’t know who was responsible, or why.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Live: News on the Attack in Nice, France
item.description: Revelers had gathered in the southern city of Nice for Bastille Day celebrations when a truck drove through the crowd.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: The Interpreter: Attack in Nice, France, Represents Terrorism’s New Reality
item.media:description: People gathered Friday in Nice, France, to leave flowers and messages and light candles to the victims of a truck driver who plowed into crowds during Bastille Day celebrations on Thursday night.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: Populations targeted by terrorists confront a danger that can be managed or policed but perhaps never entirely overcome.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: France Says Truck Attacker Was Tunisia Native With Record of Petty Crime
item.description: The man, 31, had no known links to the militant extremists who have targeted and traumatized France.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN, LILIA BLAISE, ADAM NOSSITER and AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Turkey Detains Thousands of Military Personnel in Bid to Regain Control
item.description: By noon, there were few signs that those who had taken part in the coup attempt were still able to challenge the government, and many declared the uprising a failure.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO and CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Xu Jiatun, Chinese Official Who Opposed Tiananmen Crackdown, Dies at 100
item.media:description: Xu Jiatun in 2014. He fled to the United States after the 1989 Tiananmen killings and never returned to China.
item.description: Mr. Xu, who was expelled from the Communist Party, fled to the United States in 1990.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Posters in Pakistan Urge a General to Take Control of the Government
item.media:description: Pakistani commuters passed posters of Gen. Raheel Sharif in Karachi on Tuesday.
item.description: The signs, placed by Move On Pakistan, call on the popular general Raheel Sharif to take over for an increasingly unpopular prime minister.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Defending David Against the World’s Goliaths in International Court
item.media:description: “I consider the Reagan administration to be an anomaly in terms of respect for international law. The United States does have a history of complying with the judgments of the International Court of Justice.” PAUL S. REICHLER
item.media:credit: Mary F. Calvert for The New York Times
item.description: Paul S. Reichler began his career defending the Sandinistas, and this week he added another victory: the Philippines’ case against Beijing and its claims in the South China Sea.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: U.S. and Russia Agree on Steps to Combat ISIS in Syria
item.media:description: Russia’s foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, meeting on Friday with Secretary of State John Kerry in Moscow.
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry reached a tentative deal in Moscow but did not list the terms of the agreement.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Pro-Government Forces Advance in Syria Amid Talk of U.S.-Russia Cooperation
item.media:description: A Syrian woman took shelter in a damaged building following Thursday’s airstrikes on a rebel-held neighborhood of Aleppo.
item.description: Civilians are dying from lack of food and medical care as the Syrian government tightens sieges and increases airstrikes in Aleppo and outside Damascus.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and KARAM SHOUMALI

item.title: In 9/11 Document, View of a Saudi Effort to Thwart U.S. Action on Al Qaeda
item.media:description: Former Senator Bob Graham, the Florida Democrat, led the push to have the 28-page document declassified. He had been one of the co-chairmen of the original congressional inquiry when he was in the Senate.
item.media:credit: Benjamin Rusnak for The New York Times
item.description: The 28 pages were part of the congressional inquiry into the Sept. 11 attacks, but had been kept secret out of concern that they might fray relations with Saudi Arabia.
item.dc:creator: MARK MAZZETTI

item.title: ISIS Claims Responsibility for Attack in Nice, France
item.media:description: Mourners at a makeshift memorial on the Promenade des Anglais in Nice, France, on Friday.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: The attack on a seaside promenade killed 84 people and 202 others; four acquaintances of the attacker have been detained.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN and AURELIEN BREEDEN
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Tumult in Turkey: What We Know and Don’t Know
item.media:description: Police officers protected a soldier after troops involved in a coup attempt surrendered on the Bosporus Bridge in Istanbul on Saturday.
item.description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan said the coup plotters would “pay a heavy price.” The prime minister said 265 people had been killed and more than 2,800 military personnel had been detained.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Russian Images of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 Were Altered, Report Finds
item.description: Researchers determined that two images the Russian government released after the civilian jet crashed over eastern Ukraine in 2014 had been manipulated.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Truck Attack in Nice, France: What We Know, and What We Don’t
item.description: President François Hollande said it was a terrorist attack. But the exact motivation of the assailant and whether he had accomplices remained unclear.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Sinosphere: Liberal Chinese Journal, Claiming Interference by Overseers, Files Lawsuit
item.media:description: Du Daozheng, who has been removed as publisher of the journal Yanhuang Chunqiu, in his office in Beijing in 2009.
item.media:credit: Shiho Fukada for The New York Times
item.description: The move came after the Chinese National Academy of Arts announced that Yanhuang Chunqiu’s publisher was dismissed and its chief editor was demoted.
item.dc:creator: KIKI ZHAO

item.title: North Korean Defector Surfaces in Pyongyang, Saying He Tried to Abduct Orphans
item.media:description: Ko Hyon-Chol at a news conference in Pyongyang, North Korea’s capital, on Friday. Mr. Ko said he originally fled the country in 2013.
item.description: The man, Ko Hyon-chol, said he had tried to smuggle two North Korean girls to the South at the behest of intelligence officers there.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: South Korean Villagers Pelt Premier With Eggs Over Missile Site
item.media:description: Bodyguards used umbrellas to shield Prime Minister Hwang Kyo-ahn, bottom, from eggs thrown by residents in Seongju, South Korea, on Friday.
item.description: The prime minister, Hwang Kyo-ahn, told rural residents that South Korea needed the Thaad system to defend against North Korean missiles.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Hong Kong Says Legislative Candidates Must Endorse Chinese Rule
item.media:description: The chief executive of Hong Kong, Leung Chun-ying, in June. Some scholars and lawmakers said the announcement could harm political freedoms guaranteed under law.
item.description: As calls for autonomy grow, Hong Kong’s government wants legislative candidates to pledge that the city remains an “inalienable part” of China.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: What in the World: Never Mind Grass-Fed, How About Elixir-Fed Meats?
item.description: In China, meat from livestock fed on traditional herbal remedies fetches a premium price from health-conscious shoppers.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: What in the World: When the Planets Align, Delhi Drowns in a Chorus of ‘I Do’
item.media:description: Guests dancing at a wedding in New Delhi on Sunday.
item.media:credit: Vivek Singh for The New York Times
item.description: A certain astrological configuration is considered auspicious by many Indians, and in the capital it means something very specific: a wedding apocalypse.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: What in the World: In New Zealand, Lands and Rivers Can Be People (Legally Speaking)
item.description: In a deal with Maori groups, Parliament has agreed on a way to protect natural features without them being owned by anyone, including the state.
item.dc:creator: BRYANT ROUSSEAU

item.title: How Killing of Prominent Separatist Set Off Turmoil in Kashmir
item.media:description: Indian paramilitary soldiers during curfew in Srinagar, Kashmir, on Friday.
item.description: Kashmir is divided between India and Pakistan, and Indian-administered Kashmir has long been plagued by the aftershocks of an armed insurgency in the late 1980s.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: The Women Who Are Cleaning Up
item.media:description: Theresa May.
item.description: Britain gets a female prime minister, so now politics is like housework?
item.dc:creator: JULIA BAIRD

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Cuba, a Country Frozen in Time
item.description: My land is an insular museum, stuck between the Iron Curtain and the industrial capitalism of the 1950s, and visitors view us an exotic species.
item.dc:creator: CARLOS MANUEL ÁLVAREZ

item.title: Editorial: Keeping NATO Relevant and United
item.description: Amid Russia’s aggressive tactics and Britain’s Brexit vote, the alliance serves as a regional anchor and a reassurance to Eastern European nations.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: As Refugee Family Resettles in Sweden, 9-Year-Old Nephew Dies
item.media:description: While a nurse prepares a medicine, Nabih, 9, rests in a hospital bed next to an aunt, his brother Farid and his mother Shazia Nouri, right, at a hospital in Antalya, southern Turkey.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: Ahmad Majid is one of millions of people swept up in a global refugee crisis; his resettlement in Sweden ended when his young nephew died this week.
item.dc:creator: ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Insider Podcasts: Gone: Global Warming Claims a Lake — and a Way of Life
item.media:description: The dry bed of Lake Poopó near Llapallapani.
item.description: The Andes bureau chief, Nicholas Casey, and the staff photographer Josh Haner give listeners a behind-the-scenes account of their article about a vanished lake.
item.dc:creator: SUSAN LEHMAN

item.title: Srebrenica: 21st Anniversary of Europe’s Worst Postwar Massacre
item.description: More than 8,000 men and boys were murdered in and around the city of Srebrenica in July 1995, the worst mass killing in Europe since World War II.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN
